Likely Males Urged
To Apply Tonight
Students wishing to take the
draft deferment exam on December 4 should have their applications in the mail and postmarked
no later than tomorrow, November
1, officials
Testing

of the

Service

Educational

announced

this

week.
Applications

and

mailing

en-

velopes may be obtained at any
local draft board.
In deferment of college students, regulations place emphasis
on two items, the scholatic standing of the registrant relative to all
full time male students, and his
score on the Selective Service
College Qualification Test, the socalled "draft exam."
A second test will be given
April 23, and applications to take
it should be postmarked no later
than March 9. Both tests will be
three-hour written exams.
ROTC members who did not
pass their physical exams are subject to induction, and should
therefore take the written exam
if they wish to be deferred, the
registrar's office added.

leafs will decorate the walls while
colors of brown and orange will
dominate the ceiling streamers..
The individual fraternities will
mark their groups of tables with
pumpkins carved with their respective greek letters.
Ken Luxenberg, dance chairman, based his confidence in a
highly successful dance on good
timing with the rushing schedule
and . the general spirit around
campus at this time of the year.
Tickets selling for $2 apiece
may still be purchased from any
Booster Club member or Cotillion Board salesman, Luxenberg
added.

Eisenhower by a margin of 70-47, Dave Lauman, president of the
Hopkins GOP's announced this week.
Two faculty members were undecided, making a total of 119
responses to 180 ballots. The ballots were mailed to all assistants,
associate and full professors on
the Homewood Campus. People at
Other branches of the University,

The Hopkins YMCA is sponsoring a dancing class in Levering
Great Hall. The series of ten lessons will be given by the Fred
Astaire Studios on Thursday evenings. Girls for dancing partners
aret supplied and fully guaranteed
by the Astaire Studios. No other
dancing class can make this
statement.
Cost of the lesson is one dollar
per lesson, but students must
sign up for the entire ten-lesson
course. Fox-trot, waltz, modified
jitter-bug, rhumba, samba, tango,
and mambo will be covered by
competent instructors.
Interested students can sign up
or get additional information at
the Y-Office.

good record.
Taking into consideration the relative positions of the
Hopkins athletic de-emphasis policy and that of the commercialized policies of other schools in this league, we realize that
Hopkins is not expected to produce a powerhouse. But we also
feel that Hopkins has not been out-manned on the gridiron during
the past two years with the possible exceptions of Western Maryland and Franklin and Marshall. With these points in mind we
have come to the conclusion that the Jays should be winning more
games. The Jay's Nest expressed this last year and has continued
the policy again this season.
The crux of our effort is this: we feel we have the right to
express justified editorial opinion without individuals in the
groups involved mistaking this criticism for personal insult.
In the case of letters printed in the paper, these reflect the opinions
of the authors, not necessarily of the paper. In instances where
the names are withheld we must respect the confidence of our
sources. Individuals with opinions contrary to these may express
themselves in letter form, not in brash actions. In short, we are all
individuals with individual opinions and criticisms. Degree of
perfection is directly proportional to intelligent criticism; no
gentleman in a community of scholars, if he is worthy of the
name, has the right to reject this maxim.

icy. They point to record taxes
and promise a tremendous reduction. They point to the National
Debt and promise, not only a balanced budget, but a greatly reduced debt. But, they say, they
will still increase dkense preparations and will not curtail any
social services.
Exhibit B of Republican irresponsibility is their multiple Korean policy. Would they evacuate
all American troops immediately,
like Senator Cain of Washington
wants? Would Eisenhower make a
second Munich out of Panmonjom,
as he hints? Or would he listen
to the very vocal MacArthur wing
of the Party, bomb Manchuria,
and bring on World War III? No
one knows.
Exhibit C is Joe McCarthy. To
enumerate his insinuations, distortions, fractional truths, and
outright lies would leave no room
for the remainder of this article.
Catching Communists is no job for
amateurs or children, especially
noisy ones. McCarthy has campaigned for Eisenhower, and a Republican win would be an endorsement of him.
IV—Republican Charges
The Republicans have thrown
the proverbial book at the Admin• •

specific issues on which they consistently say they disagree with the
opposition can be counted on the fingers of one hand, and among
these the malleability of the "conflicting" opinions inevitably forceS
amusement onto the scowl of objective scrutiny. A ludicrous example
of the noisy desperation and fuzziness of thought underlying the GOP
"stands" was Ike's rendition of a speceh at Kasson, Minnesota,
which jumped the promise to farmers from ninety per cent- to one
hundred per cent of parity.
There are more crucial conclusions to be drawn from the speecheS
of Eisenhower and the "crusaders" for whom he is "calling the
plays." The demagoguery that the General reads might be lesS
offensive from his lips than from those of his "squad" but the important thing is that it is there at all. Governor Stevnson's eloquence
is now so overrated and taken for granted by the Republican
spokesmen themselves that contrasting the two candidates is no
longer the order of the day but has degenerated into a picking apart
of the "upper-dog."
To sum up in a few words: we prefer the more conscientious,
more purposeful Democrats as a party; the eminently more qualified
Stevenson as a man. The Commonweal editors concluded their own
pages of reasoning concisely, and we-should like to quote them here:
Governor Stevenson continues to discuss issues, and
General Eisenhower to substitute slogans and denunciation
for a meaningful campaign . . . The full triumph of the
political primitive may be upon us. But we refuse to
'
believe it, yet.
Ours is an age of anxiety, and so it is a spawning'.
ground for the demagogue. Cynical or vicious men, at
such a time, can gain reputation and power by exploiting
anxiety and offering some easy relief. The General has
.refused to repudiate the alaramingly large number of these
men in his party, and so as the threat of their influence
becomes greater, this campaign becomes, in part, a contest
between reason and emotion, patience and frustration.

Homewood, Baltimore, October 31, 1952

Students wishing to take the
draft deferment exam on December 4 should have their applications in the mail and postmarked
no later than tomorrow, November
1, officials
Testing

of the

Service

Educational

announced

this

week.
Applications

and

mailing

en-

velopes may be obtained at any
local draft board.
In deferment of college students, regulations place emphasis
on two items, the scholatic standing of the registrant relative to all
full time male students, and his
score on the Selective Service
College Qualification Test, the socalled "draft exam."
A second test will be given
April 23, and applications to take
it should be postmarked no later
than March 9. Both tests will be
three-hour written exams.
ROTC members who did not
pass their physical exams are subject to induction, and should
therefore take the written exam
if they wish to be deferred, the
registrar's office added.

the policy again this season.
The crux of our effort is this: we feel we have the right to
express justified editorial opinion without individuals in the
groups involved mistaking this criticism for personal insult.
In the case of letters printed in the paper, these reflect the opinions
of the authors, not necessarily of the paper. In instances where
the names are withheld we must respect the confidence of our
sources. Individuals with opinions contrary to these may express
themselves in letter form, not in brash actions. In short, we are all
individuals with individual opinions and criticisms. Degree of
perfection is directly proportional to intelligent criticism; no
gentleman in a community of scholars, if he is worthy of the
name, has the right to reject this maxim.

icy. They point to record taxes
and promise a tremendous reduction. They point to the National
Debt and promise, not only a balanced budget, but a greatly reduced debt. But, they say, they
will still increase dkense preparations and will not curtail any
social services.
Exhibit B of Republican irresponsibility is their multiple Korean policy. Would they evacuate
all American troops immediately,
like Senator Cain of Washington
wants? Would Eisenhower make a
second Munich out of Panmonjom,
as he hints? Or would he listen
to the very vocal MacArthur wing
of the Party, bomb Manchuria,
and bring on World War III? No
one knows.
Exhibit C is Joe McCarthy. To
enumerate his insinuations, distortions, fractional truths, and
outright lies would leave no room
for the remainder of this article.
Catching Communists is no job for
amateurs or children, especially
noisy ones. McCarthy has campaigned for Eisenhower, and a Republican win would be an endorsement of him.
IV—Republican Charges
The Republicans have thrown
the proverbial book at the Admin• •

specific issues on which they consistently say they disagree with the
opposition can be counted on the fingers of one hand, and among
these the malleability of the "conflicting" opinions inevitably forceS
amusement onto the scowl of objective scrutiny. A ludicrous example
of the noisy desperation and fuzziness of thought underlying the GOP
"stands" was Ike's rendition of a speceh at Kasson, Minnesota,
which jumped the promise to farmers from ninety per cent- to one
hundred per cent of parity.
There are more crucial conclusions to be drawn from the speecheS
of Eisenhower and the "crusaders" for whom he is "calling the
plays." The demagoguery that the General reads might be lesS
offensive from his lips than from those of his "squad" but the important thing is that it is there at all. Governor Stevnson's eloquence
is now so overrated and taken for granted by the Republican
spokesmen themselves that contrasting the two candidates is no
longer the order of the day but has degenerated into a picking apart
of the "upper-dog."
To sum up in a few words: we prefer the more conscientious,
more purposeful Democrats as a party; the eminently more qualified
Stevenson as a man. The Commonweal editors concluded their own
pages of reasoning concisely, and we-should like to quote them here:
Governor Stevenson continues to discuss issues, and
General Eisenhower to substitute slogans and denunciation
for a meaningful campaign . . . The full triumph of the
political primitive may be upon us. But we refuse to
'
believe it, yet.
Ours is an age of anxiety, and so it is a spawning'.
ground for the demagogue. Cynical or vicious men, at
such a time, can gain reputation and power by exploiting
anxiety and offering some easy relief. The General has
.refused to repudiate the alaramingly large number of these
men in his party, and so as the threat of their influence
becomes greater, this campaign becomes, in part, a contest
between reason and emotion, patience and frustration.

Homewood, Baltimore, October 31, 1952
